Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone

ALLEGATION:
Youth was restrained after throwing computer across cabin and staff did not follow
behavior management policy.
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037

INVESTIGATION:
The allegation in full reads as follows:
Resident A was restrained due to throwing a student computer across the cabin.
Staff 1 did not follow all policy as it relates to the behavior management. Resident A
did not make any allegations, have any injuries, nor state that he felt unsafe around
Staff 1. After reviewing the cameras is when the report was made. Staff 1 did a floor
restraint, which he knew was not correct. Resident A was not injured and did not
have any complaints about the restraint. They have counseled Staff 1 and assigned
him to another unit. He has no prior history of improper restraints. He is completing
NVCI training again this week.
I interviewed Administrator 1 by phone on 3/1/2021. He reports that the incident
was reported after he reviewed the video recording of the restraint. He also reports
that Staff 1 did not follow the procedure for deescalating Resident A nor the
procedure for an appropriate restraint. He reported that Staff 1 and Staff 2 were both
“written up” for the behaviors he observed on the video recording. He also reported
that Staff 1 has been moved to another dorm and will not be allowed to have any
contact with Resident A at this time. He reports other action that is being taken
involves Staff 1 completing the NVCI (nonviolent crisis intervention) behavior
management training again and checking in with a supervisor when he begins his
shift to ensure that he is emotionally regulated. He ended by reporting that Staff 1
has no prior disciplinary action in his Human Resource file.
I interviewed Administrator 1 at the facility on 3/2/2021. He provided the name
and phone number for Staff 2 and other documentation for the three residents that
were involved in the incident.
I interviewed Resident A at the facility on 3/2/2021. He reported remembering the
incident and being restrained by Staff 1. He also reports that he is “good with it” and
“didn’t get hurt” when reporting the restraint. He reports being upset because he
missed his evening snack when he did not come out of his room when called to get
his snack. He also reports that he was mad and “threw a computer” just before Staff
1 restrained him. He reported feeling safe at the facility although he believes that he
is not getting much help with the programing at the facility. He also reported that he
just wants to go home and live with his mother, but she is not talking to him at this
time. He did report that his worker is visiting him each month and knows of his lack
of progress.
I interviewed Resident B at the facility on 3/2/2021. He reported remembering the
restraint of Resident A and being part of the restraint. He also reported that Resident
A was mad because he did not get his snack. He reports that Resident A will throw
things when upset and that is what happened just prior to Staff 1 restraining him. He
also reports hearing Staff 2 telling Staff 1 to stop the restraint. He reported that

Resident A punched Staff 1 while they were lying on the floor and Staff 1 struggled
to hold Resident A in the restraint. He stated, “Staff 1 couldn’t hold him, so I grabbed
his arm and Resident C grabbed his leg to assist with the restraint. The whole thing
only last a few seconds and was the fastest restraint I have seen.” He reported a
belief that Resident A should have been restrained because he was throwing things.
Resident B reports feelings safe at the facility and that the program is helping him
make the changes he needs.
I interviewed Resident C at the facility on 3/2/2021. He reports remembering the
incident with Resident A and that he “helped with the restraint”. He stated, “Staff 1
was trying to restrain Resident A by himself, so I grabbed Resident A’s leg and put
him in his room when the restrain was over”. He reported being Resident A’s
roommate and the person who helps him when he gets upset. He also reported that
the restraint was needed because Resident A was being unsafe when he began to
throw things around the room and “may have been trying to get at a peer he doesn’t
like”. He reports that Resident A was swearing while Staff 1 was trying to tell him to
calm down prior to the restraint. He also reports that Resident A was trying to choke
Staff 1 while they were lying on the ground, which caused him to grab Resident A’s
arm. He ended by reporting that the program has “greatly helped” him and that he
has felt safe while in the program.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 3/2/2021. He reports remembering the
incident and stated, “I know the restraint was inappropriate”. At first, he denied any
“ill will” towards Resident A but later admitted that he was emotionally dysregulated
over Resident A’s behaviors. He also reports that Resident A has a history of making
threats and acting on them. He described the situation,
We were in night procedures and I told him he can’t have any candy at
this time. Resident A told me that if he does not get what he wants, he will
not cooperate with staff. Resident A said that he would make tonight hell if
he does not get his snack. Resident A then threw a beverage on me and
walked out of the kitchen. Then he picked up a computer and threw it
across the room. This is when I attempted to put him into an interim
temporary control position, but we fell to the floor when I lost my balance. I
let him up and he walked back to his room.
Staff 1 reported making a mistake and should not have restrained Resident A. He
also reported that his technique for the restraint was not what he was taught by the
facility and that he should have focused more on the de-escalation of the situation.
He ended by admitting that he was emotionally upset over Resident A threatening to
make the unit “hell” and was “tired of Resident A” repeatedly acting out.
I interviewed the Case Manager by phone on 3/4/2021. She reports “struggling
with Resident A’s family’s resistance to communicating with him about their lack of
involvement in his treatment. She also reports being open to having a trauma
assessment completed with Resident A so the appropriate treatment can be

I interviewed Staff 2 by phone on 3/5/2021. She began the interview by stating,
“the restraint was not needed, and it was not appropriate”. She reported that
Resident A threw the computer but not in anyone’s direction. She also reported a
belief that Staff 1 was “at his wits end with Resident A”. She reports being in the
office working on resident medication when she observed the “computer in the air”.
She also reports that she came out of the office and observed “Resident A walking
away when Staff 1 grabbed him from behind and slammed him to the floor”. She
reported that she kept telling Staff 1 to let Resident A go during the restraint because
“Staff 1 was laying on top of Resident A”. She ended the interview by stating, “the
whole thing was crap”.

Incident Report: The following narrative is from the incident report (113420175)
dated 2/28/21. The staff involved are identified as Staff 1 and Staff 2, while the
resident is identified as Resident A.
After snack time, Resident A became frustrated that he could not get food
out of his snack box. He was directed to leave the kitchen and head back
to his room. Resident A walked into the common area and picked up the
student computer and threw it across the room. Staff 1 physically
intervened shortly after Resident A threw the computer. Staff 1’s physical
intervention took Resident A to the floor. Emergency procedures were
called. While on the floor, Resident C and Staff 1 helped Resident A back
to his feet. Resident A walked around the common area for a short period
of time and then walked into his room. Supervisor 1 arrived to assist and
was able to establish therapeutic rapport with Resident A. A wellness
check was done on Resident A, and he stated that he did not have any
injuries or concerns.
Behavior Management philosophy and procedures policy: The policy states the
following:
In providing residential treatment it is inevitable that there are times when
a student is out of control and will need a physical intervention. Such
situations are used when there is a clear risk of imminent harm to self, to

www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

others or in the likelihood of significant property damage. Any physical
behavior management intervention will be used as a last resort and after
nonphysical techniques are exhausted. To promote safety a team
approach (two or more staff) is the expected practice when intervening
with acting out students. Single person physical intervention should not
occur unless there is imminent risk of assault, injury, or serious property
damage and additional, staff assistance is not immediately available.
Emergency floor procedures are no longer permitted based on the new
emergency rules provided by the State. In the event that a restraint ends
up on the floor due to the student struggling the staff have the following
options:
 Disengage with the youth. If the youth is still exhibiting
dangerous behaviors and meets the criteria for physical
management, staff are able to reengage the student once he
stands up.
 Help bring the student back up to his knees or a standing
position. This needs to be done without the use of force (i.e.
dragging or pulling a student to one of these positions).
 If a student begins to struggle while in an escort or team
control, staff can utilize one of the escort positions that allow
for the student to be in a seated position.
Staff 1 Human Resources (HR) Records: As stated by Administrator 1, there is not
documentation of any disciplinary action with Staff 1 in his HR file prior to the
allegations in this report. Documentation in the file indicates that Staff 1 completed
all required training including the behavior management training (NVCI) used by the
facility along with Trauma Informed Care training. Further documentation indicates
that Staff 1 also received training in behavior management since the allegations.
Counseling Statement (write up) for Staff 1: This document states the following:
On 2/28/21 you restrained a resident and the restraint did not align with the
policy and procedures of NVCI. It was observed that you took a student to the
floor by yourself. Additionally, although the student was escalated and threw
the computer, he was walking away from you at the time, other options should
have been exercised first. This documentation also indicates that Staff 1 must
be retrained in the behavior management techniques of NVCI.
Counseling Statement (write up) for Staff 2: This document states the following:
There was an incident that resulted in a restraint with a student on 2/28/21. Your
partner engaged physically with the student and you did not assist. This is against
the teaching of NVCI, if your partner engages in physical management you must
assist to ensure the safety of both students and staff involved. You should also direct
students to their rooms during emergency procedures so that you are able to
respond to the crisis.

Investigation Summary dated 3/1/20. This document outlines the actions taken by
the facility to deal with the allegations, beginning with a review of the camera footage
and ending with the interviews.
Non-Violent Crisis Intervention Manual: I reviewed the specific physical behavior
management techniques that are approved to use at the facility. These techniques
all require two staff members and remain in the standing position for all involved.
None of the techniques reviewed (approved by the facility) match the technique used
by Staff 1 during his physical intervention with Resident A.
APPLICABLE RULE
Rule 1 Prohibition of Prone Restraint; Procedures Involving Other
Restraints in Child Caring Institutions
(2) Resident restraint must be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the
minor child's behavior, chronological and developmental
age, size, gender, physical condition, medical condition,
psychiatric condition, and personal history, including any
history of trauma, and done in a manner consistent with the
resident's treatment plan.
ANALYSIS: Evidence provided through interviews, written documentation
and a video recording do support the allegations of Staff 1 and
Staff 2 not performing an appropriate restraint of Resident A.
Both Staff 1 and Staff 2, along with Administrator 1 stated that
the restraint was not performed as required and taught to the
staff at the facility. The video recording shows that the restraint
was not according to policy and procedure.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
